Fields.DialogueText: You're certainly enjoying yourself, Axum.
Whenever we surface the submarine, I always make sure to enjoy the sunshine, Capitano.
It *is* nice after being underwater for so long.
This is a chance for the crew to get some fresh air as well.
Noted. I'll try to get as many of our crew some time to relax topside before we dive again.
Mille grazie, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: I hate being underwater all of the time.
That said, a submarine's proper place is beneath the waves. No point in pretending otherwise.
We're not safe on the surface.

Fields.DialogueText: I do empathize, Capitano. And I try to make it as comfortable as possible for you.
Actually, I'm comfortable above and below the surface.
We are not as stealthy, but I promise I will never let down my guard.
Besides, we can't avoid coming up now and then to run our diesel engines to charge the batteries.
Listen, make sure to get a full charge. I want to maximize our endurance.
Of course, Capitano. We will be ready for any—
What is it?
I believe I've spotted some trouble on the horizon.
So much for basking in the sun!
@BATTLE
Heh. Noted.
I know. And, believe me, I'm not complaining about the company down there.
It just wears on you after a while. The electric light, the taste of the air.
No offense.
None taken, believe me. I'm probably happier coming up than you are - this is literally my chance to charge my batteries.
I really don't appreciate interruptions.
Forgive me, Capitano! I was just bringing you some coffee...
Sorry. I wasn't talking about you. I was referring to the Morganas who interrupted our time under the sun.
You're sure? I can take the coffee away.

Fields.MenuText: Ha! Funny! You can just hook it to my veins now.
Please don't.
You leaving is the absolute last thing I want.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you'd miss out on the taste.
Don't look so sad! For heaven's sake, I was only joking!
Oh. Well... then, I won't.
And here's your cup.
Sorry. It's just... you're always so composed. Even in combat.
I'd like to think especially in combat, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Dammit.
@BATTLE
Thank you.
Okay. Still again you make an excellent point. I don't tell you often enough how lucky I am to be your captain.
This is true.
Thank you.
What?
But I can't hold a candle to you.
Not true.
I've never calmly told a furious admiral I can't be outglared in the middle of the worst dinner party in recorded history.
That... probably didn't actually help Margot's case. In hindsight.
No. But it still makes me smile.
Well, then, I guess it was worthwhile after ah-
We'll be ready to dive again soon. Anything on the horizon?
I see no other vessels out here, but I'm still scanning. Here, feel free to take my binoculars, Capitano.
You don't want them?
I often do better without binoculars. I prefer to use my eyes, without assistance.
I'm officially impressed. You're every bit the huntress.
Thank you, Capitano. I do my best.

Fields.MenuText: You seem to really enjoy prowling for Morganas.
Is there a reason why you seem so intense up here today?
Are you looking out for Morganas or... for something else?

Fields.DialogueText: A Belle should take pride in doing her job well. The same goes for all of our sailors, does it not?
At sea, Capitano, vigilance is always a necessity. In war, doubly so.
I am watching for anything that might be out of place.
The Morganas are unnatural, Capitano. Even without a war or without orders from Command, it would still be imperative to hunt them down.
Hunt them to extinction, I hope.
Sì. I hope so, too.
I suspect we'll have plenty of chances...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Axum! To the bridge!
Reporting as ordered, Capitano.
We have orders. Take a look.
Urgent deployment to the Aegean.
Mm-hm. Sparse on details, though I think we can make an educated guess. Lots of little islands the Morganas can haunt.
Is something wrong?
I suppose we should prepare to relocate.

Fields.MenuText: Is everything okay?
You seem reluctant to leave Africa.
... You were expecting these orders.

Fields.DialogueText: Certo. I am always ready to embrace a new opportunity.
I enjoyed being close to home, but I knew that eventually we would have to go to wherever the war needed us.
Sì. More or less.
It was only a matter of time, Capitano, before the operatives there would need our assistance.
Operatives? What are you talking about?
*sigh*
*ALARM*
Damn.
Certamente, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Before you came on board, I had a mission to-
Okay, we'll get back to this later.
We are submerged. All stations report conditions normal on the dive.
Very good. Thank you.
Will that be all, Capitano?
Not quite. Shut the door behind you, please.
Certo.
Now, about these "operatives" you mentioned before...
We have - Italy has - commandos stranded in Greece.
And you brought them there.
Just after the Morganas appeared. We deposited them on Naxos, where they had a contact - though I know they had plans to investigate other islands as well.
Had you - you, as a Belle - woken at this point? Were you walking around talking to people?
No.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
But you remember details.
Not many. I remember faces, personalities.
Mm. So, early days of the war - nobody knew what was happening. I assume they were sent to see if the Morganas were operating out of some secret base in Greek waters?
Non lo so. Your guess is as good as mine. I just-
Right. Time to fight for our lives again.
Lieutenant, show me how we're getting through these rocks.
Can I be of assistance, Capitano?
I was checking our course through the Aegean. With all of these small islands and rocky formations, it's going to be dangerous.
I will be happy to help. I have some familiarity with this location.
Right, you've been here before.

Fields.MenuText: You okay?
Is there something I should know before we get there?
That wasn't a trick question.

Fields.DialogueText: The matter is a complicated one, but I will try to keep my feelings from interfering, Capitano.
I apologize for putting you in a difficult position, Capitano.
Mi dispiace.
Perhaps, after you're done checking the navigation charts, we could talk privately?
Of course.
Molto bene. I... well, I have to complete my inspection of the torpedoes in the forward compartment.
Okay. I'll find you later, then.
*ALARM*
Ah, dammit.
@BATTLE
Sure.
... Are you sure you're all right?
I am. Grazie.
Axum? Are you still down in the torpedo room?
I am, Capitano. Our torpedo inventory is satisfactory.
I'm glad to hear it.
We are alone here for now. Perhaps we could discuss the mission.
Of course. This whole thing...

Fields.MenuText: ... makes me concerned about your well-being.
... makes me wonder if we're heading into trouble.
... seems like an itch you need to scratch.

Fields.DialogueText: È molto gentile da parte tua, Capitano. I appreciate that.
We could be, but the Morganas are only one factor.
... È vero. Perhaps when I tell you more, it will explain my awkwardness.
The impression I have is that the commandos failed to make contact with Command within a week or so of the start of their mission. Just vanished.
I think the Greeks would've made it very public if they'd captured a team of Italian soldiers working without sanction in their borders. Or killed them, if it came to that.
Sì. I suppose they would.
I have misgivings about it too, to be honest. I understand the value of information-gathering, especially in this war, but parking a bunch of commandos on dry land....
Capisco. But they were meant to be following up on some specific piece of intelligence. It wasn't random.
Somebody's coming.
Captain? Are you down here?
Aye.
Oh, Miss Axum! You're both here. We've detected a possible threat, and you're requested on the bridge at once.
Tell them I'm on my way.
Aye aye, Capitano.
Sorry. We'll get back to this when the shooting stops.
Certamente. We'll hunt these Morganas down quick.
@BATTLE
Any idea what exactly they were looking for?
No. None. I-
Morgana, or-
Both.
And then there was one coded message after that, as I understand it - I heard about it after I woke. But I don't think anything ever came of it.
Capitano?
Come in, and close the door behind you.
Before we make contact with the commandos in Greece, I need to understand the whole situation.
You said they were silent for a while, and then there was a coded message.
Sì. My old commander was told it was proof they were still alive - but that's all he was told.  I wanted to collect them then, but Command... well, Command disagreed.
They didn't want you to compromise the mission.
I suspect that was the main reason, Capitano.
Okay. You're a loyal and good officer, and I'm not going to ask if you were okay with those orders.
They were in my care, Capitano. Only for a while, but... as you say, orders are orders, and it doesn't matter if I was "okay" with them.
I don't think a group of commandos are going to blame a submarine for their problems.
I just... I brought them to Greece, so I want to support them.
That does raise one question, though: if Command wouldn't let you help before, then why are they sending us in now?
An excellent question. I can only presume that something significant has happened.
Maybe they found something big.
*ALARM*
And something else has found us.
Get us to battle stations, Axum.
@BATTLE
Though I'm pretty sure you weren't.
But I'll only feel like I've finished my work when I have those men home safe, or when I know it's not possible.
I understand.
... As it is, I just feel like I've abandoned them. Or they must think I have.
You know what I mean, though.
Yeah.
And we are.
Morgana patrol ahead!
@BATTLE
Ciao, Capitano!
Happy to be in the sunshine again, I see.
Oh, yes. Capitano, smell that air! The Mediterranean blesses us with fair winds and following seas today.
Well, I don't mean to distract you from the fresh air, but I come bringing coffee.
I'm not sure that "relaxed" is the right word. But I've had an itch for weeks, and I've finally been given permission to try to scratch it.
You know it could be dangerous. Morganas have been thick in the Aegean since week one. We can expect minefields, maybe nests....
Certo, but we can and will overcome that. If a Belle and her capitano are aligned, success follows.

Fields.MenuText: Optimistic as ever, Axum.
If I didn't know you better, I'd think you were being overconfident.
I think that's the coffee talking.

Fields.DialogueText: A bright outlook can win the day.
I should hope you know me perfectly well.
Then the coffee is very wise.
You know, though - I am not a fast vessel, Capitano. We still have plenty of time before we reach Greece.
So we do.
I'm prepared to risk it.
Just a couple of reckless daredevils, us.
Grazie, Capitano. For the coffee.
The smile when you got it was thanks enough.
YES!
You're welcome.
Are you scandalized?
No. I know what that stuff tastes like. I'm just glad you didn't knock me over.
You *do* seem more relaxed than you've been in a while.
Do you suppose that means we actually have a few minutes to just stand around and look at those amazing clouds?
The smile *and* not knocking you overboard.
Yeah. You must really like me.
... You have your good days.
I'll take it.
We're on course, Capitano. And making good time, relatively speaking.
Much as we've enjoying cloud-watching, you must be getting anxious.
But if we were to sprint, we would exhaust a great deal of our fuel for only a modest gain in speed. I am minding our endurance.
Plus, again, we're going to need to be cautious. The Morganas presumably know these waters better than many.
Have a look off the port beam, Capitano. Loggerhead turtles.
Where? I don't see anything. My eyes aren't as sharp as yours.
Look where I am pointing, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Look at it! It's bigger than I expected.
It's strange to see turtles swimming in the middle of the sea.
You're thinking about turtles in the middle of a war?

Fields.DialogueText: Nearly a meter long, some of them.
They have a reason for it.
Scusami, but loggerhead turtles are more than a mere curiosity, Capitano.
Loggerhead turtles are migratory. They must conserve their strength to travel long distances, too.
I see your point.
Oh! The turtles suddenly scattered.
Did they sense something we haven't noticed yet?
I suppose that's possible...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mm. È vero.
No startling news, Capitano. We're still on course.
Slow and steady, Axum. I don't want us hitting rocks while we're creeping around underwater.
I'm relieved to hear that.
Have you noticed? It's quite noisy in the water today.
Sorry. I think you need Belle senses for that.
*SQUEAK*
Okay. Let the record show that I'm impressed.

Fields.MenuText: Is somebody trying to communicate with us?
Whatever it is, it sounds rusty. Have the mechanics put some grease on it.
A few dolphins decided to keep us company?

Fields.DialogueText: In a manner of speaking, sì.
Haha! That would be quite comical, Capitano!
I believe so, Capitano.
*WHISTLE*
Dolphins...
Despite Morganas and war, the sea is giving us some proof of life. Comforting, no?
What do they make of you?
@BATTLE
What do you mean?
I do not think dolphins would tolerate being greased.
*ALARM*
Nothing but the best for my favorite sub.
Aw. Grazie.
Mm. Aspetta. I think I may be able to muffle some of my background noises for a second and-
The dolphins? Oh, they're extremely friendly. And they go berserk with excitement every time I stick my face out through the hull to wave at them.

Fields.MenuText: That's fair.
Are you sure it's not terror? My money would be on terror.
... I think I was happier not knowing you did that.

Fields.DialogueText: I really like them a lot.
It's not terror! Don't be so negative.
It's not like I'm going to fall out of the ship!
Well, I'm just glad you're-
Damn. If you know a way to warn the dolphins off....
They don't need to be told.
It's a little bit strange, isn't it?
What's that, Capitano?
Life under the waves.
Tell me what you mean. I... lack your perspective.
I don't think I'm about to say anything profound. It's just, here we are. A warship, a technological marvel in itself, slipping around underwater....
Sì, at about five knots.
In the middle of a global war, hiding from Morgana patrols, making our way to rendezvous with covert operatives...
And?
And here I am, drinking a cup of coffee, making comfortable conversation with the most charming Belle in the Regia Marina.
Haha! When you put it that way, it does seem a bit odd. And also, kind.
Mm.

Fields.MenuText: We're probably too relaxed, actually. We should be more careful.
I suppose I shouldn't question the luxuries that come our way.
I feel almost guilty. Times like this I'm probably as happy as I've ever been.

Fields.DialogueText: I respectfully offer a different perspective, Capitano.
The things that give us pleasure and peace are not frivolous, Capitano.
Guilt? No. Put that out of your head.
A hunter has to control their breathing to shoot accurately. Finding calm amidst difficulty provides considerable advantage.
I'll buy that.
I should admit that these quiet times... I never even imagined I'd get to have them. And maybe I'm making excuses because I don't want them to stop.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'm sorry. That was-
No, no! I'm serious! I really want to know what this is like for you.
Not that I don't believe what I'm saying, mind you.
Went without saying.
But, at the risk of sounding really self-involved, it's just been wonderful to have a taste of a life that isn't just about duty.
I'm not unhappy with my lot, and I don't have single complaint about my mission. But this...
Yeah. It is.
This is nice.
Morganas incoming!
@BATTLE
Helm, mind your rudder. We have to drive straight and narrow to get past these islands safely.
Aye aye, Capitano.
Navigating here is hazardous. How can I assist?

Fields.MenuText: Check the navigator's charts. Make sure our course is free of shoal water.
Get yourself some coffee. I need you alert.
Take the periscope for a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Capitano.
You give the best orders, Capitano.
Of course, Capitano.
There is danger in each of these small, rocky islands, whether sticking out of the water...
Or lying unseen just beneath the surface.
My hull is strong, but I would not want to test it against a pile of rocks.
Let me see...
What is it?
Recommend reducing the bell, Capitano.
Very well. Slow the engines down to bare steerageway. Are we about to hit something?
Not exactly, Capitano. If I am not mistaken, something is about to hit us.
Axum, if you know something I don't, I would rather that you just tell me-
*KNOCK*
What was that?
That is our signal. Let's surface the ship and open the hatch.
To check for damage?
Negative, Capitano. To let our visitor aboard.
We are surfaced, and the hatch is open.
Very well.
Permission... to... come... aboard, Capitano?
Granted! Axum, could you give our guest a hand?
Immediatamente!
Step carefully down the ladder. Let me help you.
Grazie, signorina. Thank you. I am exhausted...
And I am the Captain. Welcome aboard! You are?
I am Massimo, Capitano.
We can reminisce when you're steadier on your feet, soldier. Let's have our doctor look at you.
Again, mille grazie. I have much to tell you.
Did you see how bad his condition was, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: He's badly sunburned. That must be painful.
Make sure he gets some fresh water. He could be badly dehydrated.
He seems strong. I expect we can help him make a full recovery.

Fields.DialogueText: Exposure to the elements can take a heavy toll.
I will see to that personally, Capitano.
I hope you are right, Capitano.
We need to learn what happened. I have a feeling that we're going to stumble across something dangerous out here.
*ALARM*
I wonder sometimes if your words actually summon the Morganas to our location.
Fascinating theory, Axum, but we'll have to table that for now. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
And I'm Axum. I don't know if you know about Belles, but... I'm the ship.
I've heard the stories, but... you weren't here before.
I was. Just not like this.
... Do you remember me?
You smuggled chocolate onboard. It was supposed to be a secret, but you couldn't stop yourself from sharing it with your friends. And you sang this stupid song....
Heh. That's fair.
Capitano, I think our guest has recovered enough for a visit.
Let's get started then. Massimo?
Ciao, Capitano.
You look much better now than when you climbed aboard.
Crawled aboard is more like it, but that heavenly cup of coffee given to me by nostra Bella Phantasma worked wonders.

Fields.MenuText: Glad to hear it, Massimo. Are you ready to talk a bit?
Axum is quite famous for her coffee.
Good. Then let's get to business.

Fields.DialogueText: Sì, we have important matters to discuss, and quickly.
I can at least be grateful for that.
Sì, of course. Of course, Capitano.
What exactly were you doing out here?
An act of desperation, Capitano. Or perhaps an act of futility. My team and I were sent out here on a mission, but we ran into severe hardship.
This was a scouting mission?
Sì. Someone, somewhere convinced themselves that the Greeks were colluding with those... things. That they had shipyards, supply depots.
Capitano, I have to... I.... Mi dispiace.
Axum?
*ALARM*
Ah.
Kill them for me, Capitano. Please.
@BATTLE
Capitano, those ships are devils. They can poison people, they can twist people, but they don't *need* people. They just... take.
... And your men?
I don't know. I hope some of them are still alive.
We were separated days ago. In that damn mist. We were trying to help civilians - those things were just bombarding the coast, and no one could see anything. Mio Dio, we could hardly breathe.
Take your time, soldier.
Don't worry. That's my job.
Permission to enter, Capitano?
Of course, Axum.
I apologize for the end of our last conversation.
... You've been crying.
He looks ten years older now than when he was last aboard. And there's no more singing.
*ALARM*
Okay, let's go relieve some stress.
@BATTLE
What I did to those men....
You gave them a ride. If you hadn't, somebody else would've. They might not even have gotten to where they were going.
And then I left them there, even after it was clear something had gone wrong.
That was your job. You weren't ordered to go back and pick them up.
... I shouldn't say this. I know it's presumptuous.
Go on. Presume.
I think, if I had told you - even on the *first day* you came aboard - that I knew that there were soldiers that needed rescuing, you would have found a way to get us those orders.

Fields.MenuText: Actually, no. Not without more information to go on.
So what if I had? It's pretty clear they wouldn't have been at the designated extraction site.
Oh, Axum. Don't do this to yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: Capisco! I know, I know!
But they should have been able to trust that the people who sent them out would do everything in their power to see them home again. That's just the way it should work!
I know I'm not responsible for the decisions they make in Rome, but I could have done more.

Fields.MenuText: You're doing more now.
Beat yourself up after the job is done, okay?
Bull.

Fields.DialogueText: Sì. Grazie, Capitano.
Heh. Bene.
What?
We've been fighting Morganas and saving lives around the Mediterranean on more or less a daily basis since I've been here.
You had no specific reason to believe there was anything you could do to help those men, so you got on with helping the rest of the world.
I respect your sense of responsibility, and I get that you're sensitive to the idea of people being let down by their superiors - but I'm not going to tolerate anyone beating up on you unfairly.
Not even you.
Capitano....
I'd add that the one person on this ship who knows exactly what happened, from first-hand experience, thinks that you're the best thing since the invention of pasta.
Massimo thinks that?
Yes. And so do I.
*BOOM*
To the bridge! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Capitano, Signorina Axum - this coffee. I swear, you've saved my life twice.
Don't look at me. She supplies the stuff - I just rinse the pots out once in a while.
I'm just sorry I can't supply chocolate.
Ah! Listen to her, Capitano! My mother always said I should've joined the Navy!
We all have choices we regret in life, my friend.
Seriously, now. You know we're en route to your team's designated extraction coordinates. Any idea what we can expect?
I don't know. Morganas. I swear, it seemed like they were hunting us. When we crossed from Naxos to Mikonos, something huge passed by - we nearly capsized. And it-
Battleship huge? Carrier?
It was like a mountain, Capitano. I don't know what to say. There was a carrier, but that came later.
Whatever this thing was, Gaetano - bravest man you'll ever meet, but his brains just stopped growing around the time he learned to walk - Gaetano cursed at it for nearly killing us, and it heard him.
They just kept chasing us after that. They bombed Mikonos as we came to land - a stretch of beach that was deserted except for us.
And they just kept coming after that. Day after day.

Fields.MenuText: They think you saw something.
They were playing with you. It's just a game to them.
Hell. So much of what they do is just random.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I just told you what we saw. An angry floating mountain in the mist.
Some kind of drilling rig, maybe.
Bastards. Pardon me, Signorina.
È vero.
Maybe. It was heading northeast at the time, I can tell you that much.
And no signs of Greek collaboration, I take it?
No. None. Some of those crazy ba- so and sos shoot at the Morganas with their fathers' rifles from the shore, for all the good it does them.
And what about your friends?
There were more of us than the group you ferried over. We made contact with another group. We've all been blown to hell, but before I was separated there were than a dozen of us.
And they're headed for the extraction point?
Signorina, I promise you, we all spent a lot of time memorizing exactly what we had to do to make it back home alive. They're heading for the same place you are.
Glad to hear it. We should-
Morganas! Those Cattive Ragazze are relentless.
That last attack was rough. Not as much room to maneuver out here as I'd like.
I am nimble, Capitano. I would not let us be trapped like prey.
Bene. I've been trapped like prey. It's not an experience I'd recommend to others - Morganas excepted, of course.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mi dispiace.
Hm.
Mi dispiace. I'm sorry. I'm sorry it's taken me so long to come back for you. I'm sorry you had to go through what you did.
Signorina, no! What are you even talking about? Capitano, can you believe her?
She's been worried sick about you, Sergente. Apparently she's been digging around for word that you boys were safe ever since she first woke.
No!
Well... you were my guests. Of course I worried. And you were all alone out there.
Mamma mia. I really should have joined the Regia Marina!
Capitano...

Fields.MenuText: In fact, she's been kicking herself over not withdrawing from our last couple of missions to go hunt for you herself.
She's the big sister you never knew you had.
She takes her responsibilities to the people she protects very seriously.

Fields.DialogueText: Signorina, we were just doing our duty, the same as anyone else. I can't believe that you even noticed us, let alone...
*sniff*
When this war is over, you and the Capitano have to come visit me. My wife... well, she may have preferred the peace while I was gone, but she'll forgive you. And she makes the most amazing-
I... should have said that sooner.
Axum can't actually leave the ship, but hold that thought.
The navigator is ready for you to approve the charts, Capitano.
I already have. It's a course through dangerous waters at high speed.
It was the fastest way to get to the coordinates that Massimo provided.

Fields.MenuText: It's worth the risk.
Is this wise? Maybe there's a safer way.
I assume you're up for this.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you agree with me, Capitano.
The longer we take to get there, the lower the odds of a successful rescue, Capitano.
We are the only ones who can rescue them, Capitano. We cannot delay.
We don't have any other choice, do we?
I brought those people here, into danger. I am responsible for bringing them out.
I know. Massimo's wife won't feed us otherwise.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Capitano.
You know I'm joking.
So, are you feeling any better now that you've cleared the air?
I... sì. *bashful grin*
You didn't have to tell him I was making a big deal of it, though.

Fields.MenuText: The fact that you were begging for forgiveness was already kind of a clue.
Apologies.
I regret nothing.

Fields.DialogueText: I wasn't "begging." I was-
Oh, stop. No apologies are-
Ha! Of course you-
*sigh*
Morgana patrol on our tail!
@BATTLE
Damage report!
The last Morgana exchange battered our hull, but damage control efforts were successful. We are still fully seaworthy.
That was too close.
What are you talking about, Capitano?
I'm talking about those rocks.
I felt the hull shudder, so you must have felt it, too. We almost ran aground on that island, didn't we?
It was only a scrape. I paid it no mind.

Fields.MenuText: As long as you have this under control.
You're tough as nails. If I stubbed my toe that hard on a rock, I'd be in tears!
That's what I'm afraid of.

Fields.DialogueText: I am quite focused, Capitano. I promise you we are fine.
An interesting comparison, but I promise I am fine.
There was hardly any damage. I assure you, it was nothing.
I know you want to rescue Massimo's team as fast as you can...
... but let's make sure nobody has to rescue us first, capisci?
Capisco.
Can we run further to the east? I need to get us closer to the islands.
Massimo, this is as close as we're going to get.
I want to make sure we can spot survivors.

Fields.MenuText: Axum has a sharp eye.
We can't extract anybody if we're stuck on the rocks.
When you command a submarine, you can decide how close is too close.

Fields.DialogueText: That is true. If my people are out here, she'll see something.
Of course, but you must understand the urgency.
*sigh* Understood, Capitano.
Any sign yet?
None, but we are still several nautical miles away from the exact coordinates.
Keep looking. If we're lucky, we might see signs of a camp, or maybe a raft.
And if we aren't lucky?
Then we might spot a pack of Morganas instead, ambushing us in these narrow straits.
I am looking out for that, too.
Make sure to keep enough water below us in case we need to dive.
*ALARM*
Easier said than done, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Grazie, Signorina.
More Morganas...
@BATTLE
According to the navigator's charts, we're at Massimo's rally point. Anything yet?
Still nothing.
Nothing at all?
I thought I saw the remains of a campfire on one of the islands, but I'm not certain. Besides that, I saw nothing else.

Fields.MenuText: It's something. Don't give up.
Keep looking. They could be on any of these islands.
Maybe we should get Massimo up here with a pair of binoculars. He may have a better idea of what to look for.

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, Capitano - I won't.
I'll keep searching.
I think he's sleeping now, Capitano. And he needs the rest.
Over there on that island, on the port side. Is that...
I see it too! Boats on the beach?
Calling those things boats is generous. They look like makeshift rafts at best.
But there are people... Capitano, it's some of the commandos! There they are!
I'm shooting a flare to get their attention.
That may draw the Morganas to our position.
A risk we have to take. Inform Massimo that he should get ready to recover his team.
At once! Capitano?
Yes, Axum?
Thank you.
I agree he needs the rest, but I'll bet you he's not... hey.
Hey.
The final raft is alongside, Capitano.
Get those people aboard quickly. We're diving as soon as the last one is inside.
Massimo is helping them, but I am not sure we'll be done in time.
In time for what?
In time to escape the Morgana counterattack.

Fields.MenuText: Stay positive, Axum. We'll make it.
I'm worried about it, too.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you are right.
But we will not flinch.
We will stay until every one of them is aboard. Nobody will be left behind this time.
Keep the torpedoes ready, Axum.
Aye aye, Capitano.
All we can do is our best.
*ALARM*
Dark shapes on the horizon, Axum?
I see them, too.
@BATTLE
You look tired.
The Morgana pursuit is relentless. I am... feeling fatigued.

Fields.MenuText: It must be bad. I've never heard you admit something like that before.
We're almost through their line.
We can handle them.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed.
One way or another, this hunt is near its end.
Certo. We will persevere.
Just hang in there a little bit longer. People are counting on us.
I would never desert you, Capitano.
I know. I would never desert you, either.
All of the surviving commandos are accounted for. We saved nine of them.
I've seen the bomb sites on the beaches as we've searched. They did a hell of a job staying alive.
It beat the alternative.
Well said. Now, get below and regroup with your people, Massimo. Get them hydrated, then introduce them to either their bunks or the best damn coffee on the planet.
And Signorina - I'll make sure they know they weren't forgotten.
Hear that, Axum? Nine survivors. Let's get them home.
Sì, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Ha. You're one to talk.
I'm serious, Axum. How're you holding up?
Of course. Grazie, Capitano.
May I come in, Capitano?
If that's your coffee I smell, the answer is always yes.
Am I too predictable?
I like that we have become familiar to each other, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: I like it, too.
We've been through a lot together. I should hope that we are.
So that's an affectionate "yes?"

Fields.DialogueText: I'm happy to hear that.
We are. And I wanted to talk about that.
Maybe I can put it another way.
We've been successful in so many things, Capitano.
You brought us through a lot of tough battles, Axum. I always knew I could count on you.
And when things were toughest, I always knew I could count on you. Always.
A Belle and her captain need to be close.
A hunter always wants to get closer to her target, but she has to be cautious. Getting too close might...
Scare away what she wants?
You understand me, Capitano?
Perfectly.
Are you sure?
There's no scaring me away, Axum.
Well, then. Let's see how this hunt ends.
... You can put the coffee down over there. I bet it'll still be good cold.
